comments.body:
I'm thinking about what APIs we should provide here. We should at least have the `get` API to get the result and wait until it's available. We should also provide APIs with a timeout. Some ideas:
1. `def get(time: Long, unit: TimeUnit)`, which is similar to [LinkedBlockingQueue.poll](https://docs.oracle.com/javase/7/docs/api/java/util/concurrent/LinkedBlockingQueue.html#poll(long,%20java.util.concurrent.TimeUnit))
2. `waitCompleted` and users can call `get` later if it returns true.

It looks to me that `def get(time: Long, unit: TimeUnit)` should be good enough and people can do try-catch if they want to handle timeout differently. It's better to start with less public APIs as we can always add later.

I find the `time` parameters more suitable with `waitCompleted`, and `get` should be the argument-less method.

Calling `get` without a successful `waitCompleted` should throw an `NoSuchElementException` or `IllegalStateException`.

What do you think about returning false on timeout and true on success? A timeout is not really an exceptional situation as it is something you can expect when you wait for something give a timeout.
then shall we have a variant of `waitCompleted` that w/o a timeout?
Well, a `waitCompleted` w/o a timeout is not really needed when we have `get` w/o a timeout. I have removed `reset` and even `close` as we use it only once.
looks like this class is thread safe?
The only thing we need to protect is the `register` method, and we can simply add `synchronized`.
Now that we do not have the `reset` method any more, it looks like the only race-condition that can occur is inside `register`, so yes, Observation can made thread-safe then.
shall we also mention the `on` API here?
It does not really add something substantial to the API. I can make it `private[spark]`. It is more a convenient hook for `Dataset.observe`.
private[spark] SGTM
done

comments.body: This is in essence an asynchronous API. You never know when the computation actually finishes, and in most cases you are only interested in it when it produces a result. So why are we introducing concepts like wait & get? To me it would be more logical to make this return a Future. In that case the user can compose a further computation using that & if they need the blocking API they can just use Future.get/await.
That's a good point! We can simply leverage the standard `Future` API to represent this async result.

This `Observation` is trying hiding multi-threading from the user for use cases where they simply want a metric after they have called an action on a Dataset. Adding async notion to the API does not contribute to that goal.

The `waitCompleted` is an edge case, usually you simply call `Observation.get`. If the user wanted a Future, they could wrap the `Observation.get` with one. What you are proposing would mean that everyone else who does not want a `Future` would get a `Future` and has to call `.value` to get an `Option[Try[Row]]` and deal with this result where `Observation.get` now returns the `Row`. I do not see where the Future simplifies the API.

Maybe you can sketch this out a bit more on how it would look like for the user of `Observation` so the benefits become clearer.
We can still keep the `get` API, but returning `Future` should be a more standard way for users to do async than `waitCompleted`.

We can remove the public `waitCompleted` and only provide `get`. If they want a `Future`, they can

    val f = Future { observation.get }

and they want a timeout, they can do:

    Await.result(f, 2 seconds)
SGTM
